sub_title: Honorary Researcher Njala Uni. SL-WUR NL, Field Coordinator Gola Rain Forest SL and SCNL Liberia, RA UCL UK
summary:
Created new development protocols for a real focus group discussions for evaluation of livelihood activities (for Forest Conservation) on forest edge communities and Ebola Impacts on Local Institutions.

Develop research protocols for both quantitative qualitative methods

Using strategic consultation (local) method(s) to get information to societal heads about their concepts and preventions of Aids and Ebola in SL (the role of societal heads for Aids and Ebola preventions)

Evaluate and advise on the effect of Community Care Centres for Ebola in Sierra Leone

Member of the Advisory committee for the Ebola Platform  of  IDS Institute of Development Studies Sussex UK

Training and supervising Research Assistants and Data Entry Clerks on developmental activities

Research Assistant for the effect of West African Women Traders on London Economic

Research NL', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2010}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'company': 'Njala_Wageningen  University Research  Sierra Leone_Netherlands', 'description': 'Between 1984 and 1993 Esther Mokuwa worked as a primary school teacher, secretary and computer technician (Njala University).  She then took a career break to raise a family.  She completed her higher education in Britain (2006-2009), qualifying in software engineering and engineering management (University of Greenwich).  In 2009 she researched humanitarian supply chains in central Sierra Leone, for an MSc dissertation.  Since 2009 she has worked as a researcher in Liberia and Sierra Leone, supervising several large-scale socio-economic data gathering exercises for Wageningen, Cambridge, Chicago and Njala Universities, including rural socio-economic baseline studies of communities around the Gola forest (Sierra Leone and Liberia). This work involved managing field teams of up to 30-40 enumerators working in remote rural conditions, and supervision of computerised data entry. She has also managed several socio-economic field survey exercises for Njala University commissioned and funded by FAO.  In addition to her current work on the Njala-Wageningen research cooperation scheme she is also writing a PhD in social sciences at Njala with supervision from Professor Erwin Bulte (Development Economics, Wageningen) to be based on publications (e.g. Mokuwa et al. 2011).  Her thematic focus is on cultural variables (kinship, marriage exchanges, gift giving and sacrifice) to see how these affect economic development and market integration in rural Sierra Leone.', 'title': 'Coordinator (0.8 FTE), Expert in Focus Group  Dis & Liveli.
